item.title: Welp, I did it.
item.dc:creator: Blake Winton
item.description:
As I mentioned in a previous post, I wasn‚Äôt really excited by the new MacBooks that were announced this year. And the more I read the less compelling they seemed‚Ä¶ As I talked with my co-workers, I heard some really good reviews of a couple of models of Windows computers, and since 90% of Firefox‚Äôs users are using Windows it‚Äôs probably not such a bad idea if I use it, too, both to help me understand the problems they‚Äôre running into, and to make sure that the code I‚Äôm writing will work for them.

So on Friday I bit the bullet and ordered a Dell XPS 15 (with Touch screen, 32Gb RAM, and a 1Tb SSD) for my latest laptop refresh. I think that the recent updates to the Windows Subsystem for Linux will let me do all the same Unix-y stuff I‚Äôve been doing on the Mac, and if I use the same keyboard and trackpad, I‚Äôm not sure I‚Äôll notice much of a difference, to be honest.

It‚Äôs going to be a few weeks before it arrives, which is nice because it lets me think about all the stuff I‚Äôll need to transfer over, and because it lets Mike Hoye go through all the pain of switching before I do, so I can hopefully avoid the worst pitfalls. üòâ There is, of course, a guide to switching for Mozilla people, but it‚Äôs pretty out of date. I‚Äôll probably be updating it as I run into stuff, and hopefully the other people who are also switching will do the same.

So, here‚Äôs the big list of stuff I currently use, and replacements (where I know what they are):

First off, the obvious ones:

  • Slack ‚áí Slack
  • Firefox ‚áí Firefox
  • Twitter ‚áí Twitter
  • Crashplan ‚áí Crashplan
  • Chrome ‚áí Chrome

Next, the slightly more complicated ones:

  • iTerm2 ‚áí Cmder
    Cmder isn‚Äôt the same, but it‚Äôs the best Windows terminal app I‚Äôve found.
    Update: I might go with ConEMU, the program underlying Cmder, instead.
  • Safari ‚áí Also Chrome. Or maybe Edge.
    I use Safari mostly for YouTube. I used to use Chrome for this; maybe I‚Äôll go back, or maybe it‚Äôs time to try a new browser. I hear Edge has really good battery life while watching video‚Ä¶ üôÇ
  • Atom ‚áí Atom (or Visual Studio Code?)
    I‚Äôve heard not-great things about Atom on Windows, so I‚Äôm starting to look into switching to Visual Studio Code. So far it seems okay‚Ä¶ I do miss the minimap and Whimsy.
  • Dropbox ‚áí Dropbox (or Google Drive, or CloudApp?)
    Mozilla moved to Google Apps for our email, and now we have a big shared space there. Should we really still be paying for Dropbox Pro accounts for our team? Maybe not‚Ä¶ Of course, I don‚Äôt think Google Drive uploads screenshots automatically, so maybe I‚Äôll also need to install CloudApp for that?
  • Acorn ‚áí Paint.net
    Totally not the same, but I think paint.net will do most of the stuff I want.

After that is the software I‚Äôm unsure about alternatives for:

  • LimeChat
    I‚Äôve been looking for a while, but still haven‚Äôt found a beautiful IRC client for Windows. (Please don‚Äôt suggest mIRC, or irssi over ssh‚Ä¶ Anyone who considers those ‚Äúbeautiful‚Äù clearly doesn‚Äôt share my aesthetic. üòù) The closest I‚Äôve found has been Foo IRC, but I‚Äôm not sure how well it works. For some reason I had a pinned tab open on IceChat‚Äôs page, but I‚Äôm not a big fan of how it looks‚Ä¶
    Update: IRC Explorer looks pretty nice, too‚Ä¶
  • Mail.app
    I‚Äôm not really enthused with Apple‚Äôs Mail app, but it‚Äôs not terrible. I hear Microsoft‚Äôs Mail app is pretty similar, so I‚Äôll give it a try.
  • XScope
    I don‚Äôt think there is anything like XScope on Windows 10. I might just have to go back to my Mac for the kinda stuff I use it for‚Ä¶ Update: PicPick looks like it might do some of the stuff XScope does‚Ä¶

And things I just don‚Äôt know about:

  • Calendar.app
    I‚Äôm sure there‚Äôs something on Windows that does calendaring, but will it connect to my home iCal account?
  • Things
    I don‚Äôt use this a ton these days, but it‚Äôs good for keeping track of what‚Äôs on my plate. I may just continue to use it on my iPhone‚Ä¶
  • iTunes
    I don‚Äôt think WinAmp or iTunes for Windows are really what I‚Äôm looking for here. I might switch to a combination of Spotify and my iPhone.
  • Anvil
    Do I still need to run folders as websites? Maybe not so much these days, since I‚Äôm using webpacka lot more, and it comes with a dev server.
  • Quicksilver
    I think I could probably use the Cortana search menu for most of what I use Quicksilver for‚Ä¶
  • aText
    This is another one of those ‚ÄúThere has to be something like this‚Äù apps, but I have no idea what it is.

Suggestions for any of the apps mentioned above would be very appreciated!

item.title: My problems with the new MacBooks.
item.dc:creator: Blake Winton
item.description:
I was listening to episode 193 of the Accidental Tech Podcast, and one of the hosts didn‚Äôt seem like he understood why I (and apparently many other people on Twitter1) were uninterested or annoyed or disappointed with the new MacBook Pros. So, being a random white dude on the Internet, I hoped that I could leave a comment explaining the various reasons, in case he was interested‚Ä¶ üôÇ

Read more‚Ä¶ (4 min remaining to read)

item.title: Hey! Let‚Äôs Write a WebExtension!
item.dc:creator: Blake Winton
item.description:
(This article is also posted on Mozilla Hacks.)

You might have heard about Mozilla‚Äôs WebExtensions, our implementation of a new browser extension API for writing multiprocess-compatible add-ons. Maybe you‚Äôve been wondering what it was about, and how you could use it. Well, I‚Äôm here to help! I think MDN‚Äôs WebExtensions Docs have a pretty great definition:

WebExtensions are a new way to write Firefox extensions.

The technology is developed for cross-browser compatibility: to a large extent the API is compatible with the extension API supported by Google Chrome and Opera. Extensions written for these browsers will in most cases run in Firefox with just a few changes. The API is also fully compatible with multiprocess Firefox.

The only thing I would add is that while Mozilla is implementing most of the API that Chrome and Opera support, we‚Äôre not restricting ourselves to only that API. Where it makes sense, we will be adding new functionality and talking with other browser makers about implementing it as well. Finally, since the WebExtension API is still under development, it‚Äôs probably best if you use Firefox Nightly for this tutorial, so that you get the most up-to-date, standards-compliant behaviour. But keep in mind, this is still experimental technology ‚Äî things might break!

Starting off

Okay, let‚Äôs start with a reasonably simple add-on. We‚Äôll add a button, and when you click it, it will open up one of my favourite sites in a new tab.

Read more‚Ä¶ (9 min remaining to read)

item.title: ES6 Templates
item.dc:creator: Blake Winton
item.description:
One of my favourite upcoming features in ES6 is Template Strings. I‚Äôve used JQuery‚Äôs templates in some previous code I‚Äôve worked on, and while it was very useful in finishing the feature on time, it‚Äôs aged now and relying on third-party libraries which we don‚Äôt have time to keep up to date isn‚Äôt the best idea and so we‚Äôre in the middle of some work to remove them. So having said that, I‚Äôm quite happy to see something similar arriving in the base language, so that we can take advantage of it without having to add any extra code.

As an aside, all the code below was tested in Firefox 34, using the Scratchpad. The comments are pasted in below the code when you select it and choose the Execute ¬ª Display menu item or hit Ctrl+L (Cmd+L on Mac). I hear they also work in Chrome, but they didn‚Äôt seem to in the version I was running (39.0.2171.95), and I didn‚Äôt want to start messing with an --es-staging flag. If someone can confirm whether they work or not, I would certainly appreciate it! :)

Read more‚Ä¶ (5 min remaining to read)

item.title: New Year‚Äôs Resolutions‚Ä¶
item.dc:creator: Blake Winton
item.description:
Well, I managed to spend New Year‚Äôs Eve lying sick on the couch, and then went to bed semi-delirious from lack of sleep at 12:08, which kind of sucked, but I‚Äôm still hopeful that 2015 will be better than 2014 was. I mean, it almost has to be, right?

Anyways, my first, and so far only, resolution is to consume less and create more. When I look back on the year, I find I have spent more of my free time than I‚Äôld like passively consuming other people‚Äôs content instead of making new things of my own, and that kind of bothers me. I‚Äôm very glad that a large part of my job involves making things, and that has definitely been rewarding, but there are also a lot of personal projects I want to start or finish or just push forward. And it doesn‚Äôt have to be code. I‚Äôld like to write more blog posts, to explain the things I‚Äôm doing, and why they interest me enough to spend time on.

item.title: Meet the new blog, same as the old blog.
item.dc:creator: Blake Winton
item.description:
One of the things I did over the holidays (so far) is upgrade the software that powers the blog.

Read more‚Ä¶ (1 min remaining to read)

item.title: Listening to things‚Ä¶
item.dc:creator: Blake Winton
item.description:
In high school and university, I used to listen to a lot of music. As I went about my day, there would continually be something on the cd player. But these days I find myself listening to podcasts1 in my spare audio time instead, and that strikes me as interesting because without meaning to I seem to have moved from (largely) mass-produced, mass-marketed entertainment to (mostly) independent, informational2 entertainment.

  1. The list, in alphabetical order, is: Accidental Tech Podcast ‚Ä¢ After Dark ‚Ä¢ Bitsplitting ‚Ä¢ Core Intuition ‚Ä¢ Edge Cases ‚Ä¢ Fear the Boot ‚Ä¢ Isometric ‚Ä¢ JavaScript Jabber ‚Ä¢ LESS THAN LIVE with KATE OR DIE ‚Ä¢ Lostcast ‚Ä¢ No Such Thing As A Fish ‚Ä¢ The Diecast ‚Ä¢ The Dungeons & Dragons Podcast ‚Ä¢ The Incomparable ‚Ä¢ The Stack Exchange Podcast ‚Ä¢ The Web Ahead ‚Ä¢ Total Party Kill ‚Ä¢ Webcomics Weekly¬†‚Ü©

  2. I‚Äôll readily agree that most of the things I learn aren‚Äôt going to impact my life in any significant way. I‚Äôm not going to read many comics, or play many role-playing games, or do, uh, whatever QI does, but they‚Äôre still fun to listen to. :)¬†‚Ü©

item.title: Minecraft and orcs.
item.dc:creator: Blake Winton
item.description:
I‚Äôve been playing a bunch of Minecraft on a survival-mode server recently, and it occurred to me that when I‚Äôm playing, I basically act like an orc ‚Äî cutting down all the trees, digging up all the stone, killing all the animals ‚Äî all so that I can build whatever fancy strikes my mind.

In my normal life, I bike (or take public transit) for all my trips; I recycle cans, bottles, cardboard boxes; I compost vegetables in my back yard, and other organic waste through the city‚Äôs compost program; I keep the house fairly cool in winter, and we barely ran our (window) air conditioner at all this summer. But as soon as I log on to the server all the normal behaviour is right out the window.

Maybe when I build a house of my own, I‚Äôll try to only use sustainable materials, and see how it is to live in a Minecraft world‚Ä¶

item.title: New kinds of thoughts.
item.dc:creator: Blake Winton
item.description:
Earlier in my life, I would have looked at the new window in the door, and thought ‚ÄúNice! They must have put that in so that people wouldn‚Äôt slam the door into other people when they opened it.‚Äù But now I find myself thinking ‚ÄúNice! They probably put that in so that people wouldn‚Äôt slam the door into other people when they opened it, but it also has the beneficial effect of letting people know if there‚Äôs someone lurking in the stairwell before they open the door.‚Äù I‚Äôm not completely sure what‚Äôs changed in my life (other than I‚Äôm exposing myself to more varied viewpoints than I did when I was younger), but it seems like a positive thing from where I‚Äôm standing.

(There are a bunch of things I‚Äôve been thinking recently, and they don‚Äôt tend to fit in 140 characters, so I‚Äôm going to try and post more of them here)
